natural problem: When the base-$b$ number $11011_b$ is multiplied by $b-1$, then $1001_b$ is added, what is the result (written in base $b$)?
natural solution: We can write out what $11011_b$ means in terms of powers of $b$: $$11011_b = b^4+b^3+b+1.$$Multiplying this by $b-1$ gives \begin{align} 11011_b &= (b-1)b^4 + (b-1)b^3 + (b-1)b + (b-1) \\ &= b^5 - b^4 + b^4 - b^3 + b^2 - b + b - 1 \\

&= b^5 - b^3 + b^2 - 1. \end{align}Now $$1001_b = b^3 + 1,$$so when we add this to the result above, we get $b^5+b^2$, which is written in base $b$ as $\boxed{100100}$. Instead of taking this algebraic approach, you can also think in terms of base-$b$ long arithmetic (note that each $(b-1)$ below represents a single digit): $$\begin{array}{r *5{c@{~}}c}

+ &&& 1 & 0 & 0 & 1 \\ \hline & 1 & 0 & 0 & 1 & 0 & 0 \end{array}$$Note that no carries are needed in the multiplication step, since $b-1$ is a digit in base $b$. Carries are needed in the addition step, since $(b-1)+1=10_b$.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem 
fixes b :: int
assumes h0 : "b > 1"
and h1 : "base b (11011_b) * (b - 1) + base b (1001_b) = base b (100100_b)"
shows  "base b (100100_b) = base b (100100_b)"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 When the base-$b$ number $11011_b$ is multiplied by $b-1$, then $1001_b$ is added, what is the result (written in base $b$)? The final Answer is 100100
 ### Proof
 We can write out what $11011_b$ means in terms of powers of $b$: $$11011_b = b^4+b^3+b+1.$$Multiplying this by $b-1$ gives \begin{align} 11011_b &= (b-1)b^4 + (b-1)b^3 + (b-1)b + (b-1) \\ &= b^5 - b^4 + b^4 - b^3 + b^2 - b + b - 1 \\
 &= b^5 - b^3 + b^2 - 1. \end{align}Now $$1001_b = b^3 + 1,$$so when we add this to the result above, we get $b^5+b^2$, which is written in base $b$ as $\boxed{100100}$. Instead of taking this algebraic approach, you can also think in terms of base-$b$ long arithmetic (note that each $(b-1)$ below represents a single digit): $$\begin{array}{r *5{c@{~}}c}
 && 1 & 1 & 0 & 1 & 1 \\ \times &&&&&& (b-1) \\ \hline && (b-1) & (b-1) & 0 & (b-1) & (b-1) \\ \\ \\ & \stackrel{1}{\phantom{(0)}} & \stackrel{1}{(b-1)} & (b-1) & \stackrel{1}{\phantom{(}0\phantom{)}} & \stackrel{1}{(b-1)} & (b-1) \\
 + &&& 1 & 0 & 0 & 1 \\ \hline & 1 & 0 & 0 & 1 & 0 & 0 \end{array}$$Note that no carries are needed in the multiplication step, since $b-1$ is a digit in base $b$. Carries are needed in the addition step, since $(b-1)+1=10_b$.
 *)

theorem 
fixes b :: int
assumes h0 : "b > 1"
and h1 : "base b (11011_b) * (b - 1) + base b (1001_b) = base b (100100_b)"
shows  "base b (100100_b) = base b (100100_b)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Given a base $b$ such that $b > 1$, if the base $b$ representation of $11011$ times $(b - 1)$ plus the base $b$ representation of $1001$ equals the base $b$ representation of $100100$, prove that the base $b$ representation of $100100$ is equal to the base $b$ representation of $100100$.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes b :: nat and f :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f x = (x in base b) * (b - 1) + (1001 in base b)"
shows  "f (11011 in base b) = (100100 in base b)"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 When the base-$b$ number $11011_b$ is multiplied by $b-1$, then $1001_b$ is added, what is the result (written in base $b$)? The final Answer is 100100
 ### Proof
 We can write out what $11011_b$ means in terms of powers of $b$: $$11011_b = b^4+b^3+b+1.$$Multiplying this by $b-1$ gives \begin{align} 11011_b &= (b-1)b^4 + (b-1)b^3 + (b-1)b + (b-1) \\ &= b^5 - b^4 + b^4 - b^3 + b^2 - b + b - 1 \\
 &= b^5 - b^3 + b^2 - 1. \end{align}Now $$1001_b = b^3 + 1,$$so when we add this to the result above, we get $b^5+b^2$, which is written in base $b$ as $\boxed{100100}$. Instead of taking this algebraic approach, you can also think in terms of base-$b$ long arithmetic (note that each $(b-1)$ below represents a single digit): $$\begin{array}{r *5{c@{~}}c}
 && 1 & 1 & 0 & 1 & 1 \\ \times &&&&&& (b-1) \\ \hline && (b-1) & (b-1) & 0 & (b-1) & (b-1) \\ \\ \\ & \stackrel{1}{\phantom{(0)}} & \stackrel{1}{(b-1)} & (b-1) & \stackrel{1}{\phantom{(}0\phantom{)}} & \stackrel{1}{(b-1)} & (b-1) \\
 + &&& 1 & 0 & 0 & 1 \\ \hline & 1 & 0 & 0 & 1 & 0 & 0 \end{array}$$Note that no carries are needed in the multiplication step, since $b-1$ is a digit in base $b$. Carries are needed in the addition step, since $(b-1)+1=10_b$.
 *)

theorem
fixes b :: nat and f :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f x = (x in base b) * (b - 1) + (1001 in base b)"
shows  "f (11011 in base b) = (100100 in base b)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: A function $f$ is defined such that for any natural number $x$, $f(x)$ equals to $x$ in base $b$ times $b - 1$ plus $1001$ in base $b$. Prove that $f(11011$ in base $b$) equals to $(100100$ in base $b$).

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes b :: nat and f :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. f n = n * (b - 1) + 9"
shows  "f 11011 = 100100"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 When the base-$b$ number $11011_b$ is multiplied by $b-1$, then $1001_b$ is added, what is the result (written in base $b$)? The final Answer is 100100
 ### Proof
 We can write out what $11011_b$ means in terms of powers of $b$: $$11011_b = b^4+b^3+b+1.$$Multiplying this by $b-1$ gives \begin{align} 11011_b &= (b-1)b^4 + (b-1)b^3 + (b-1)b + (b-1) \\ &= b^5 - b^4 + b^4 - b^3 + b^2 - b + b - 1 \\

Instead of taking this algebraic approach, you can also think in terms of base-$b$ long arithmetic (note that each $(b-1)$ below represents a single digit): $$\begin{array}{r *5{c@{~}}c}
 && 1 & 1 & 0 & 1 & 1 \\ \times &&&&&& (b-1) \\ \hline && (b-1) & (b-1) & 0 & (b-1) & (b-1) \\ \\ \\ & \stackrel{1}{\phantom{(0)}} & \stackrel{1}{(b-1)} & (b-1) & \stackrel{1}{\phantom{(}0\phantom{)}} & \stackrel{1}{(b-1)} & (b-1) \\
 + &&& 1 & 0 & 0 & 1 \\ \hline & 1 & 0 & 0 & 1 & 0 & 0 \end{array}$$Note that no carries are needed in the multiplication step, since $b-1$ is a digit in base $b$. Carries are needed in the addition step, since $(b-1)+1=10_b$.
 *)

theorem
fixes b :: nat and f :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. f n = n * (b - 1) + 9"
shows  "f 11011 = 100100"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: Given a function $f(n) = n * (b - 1) + 9$ for all natural numbers $n$, find the value of $f(11011)$ such that it equals $100100$.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes b :: int and f :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "b > 1"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. f n = n * (b - 1) + (1001 :: int)"
and h2 : "f (11011 :: int) = (100100 :: int)"
shows  "f (11011 :: int) = 100100"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 When the base-$b$ number $11011_b$ is multiplied by $b-1$, then $1001_b$ is added, what is the result (written in base $b$)? The final Answer is 100100
 ### Proof
 We can write out what $11011_b$ means in terms of powers of $b$: $$11011_b = b^4+b^3+b+1.$$Multiplying this by $b-1$ gives \begin{align} 11011_b &= (b-1)b^4 + (b-1)b^3 + (b-1)b + (b-1) \\ &= b^5 - b^4 + b^4 - b^3 + b^2 - b + b - 1 \\

Instead of taking this algebraic approach, you can also think in terms of base-$b$ long arithmetic (note that each $(b-1)$ below represents a single digit): $$\begin{array}{r *5{c@{~}}c}
 && 1 & 1 & 0 & 1 & 1 \\ \times &&&&&& (b-1) \\ \hline && (b-1) & (b-1) & 0 & (b-1) & (b-1) \\ \\ \\ & \stackrel{1}{\phantom{(0)}} & \stackrel{1}{(b-1)} & (b-1) & \stackrel{1}{\phantom{(}0\phantom{)}} & \stackrel{1}{(b-1)} & (b-1) \\
 + &&& 1 & 0 & 0 & 1 \\ \hline & 1 & 0 & 0 & 1 & 0 & 0 \end{array}$$Note that no carries are needed in the multiplication step, since $b-1$ is a digit in base $b$. Carries are needed in the addition step, since $(b-1)+1=10_b$.
 *)

theorem
fixes b :: int and f :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "b > 1"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. f n = n * (b - 1) + (1001 :: int)"
and h2 : "f (11011 :: int) = (100100 :: int)"
shows  "f (11011 :: int) = 100100"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: For a function $f$ defined such that $f(n) = n * (b - 1) + 1001$ for all integers $n$, where $b > 1$, prove that $f(11011) = 100100$.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes b :: nat
assumes h0 : "b > 1"
shows  "(b^4 + b^3 + b + 1)*(b - 1) + b^3 + 1 = b^5 + b^2"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 When the base-$b$ number $11011_b$ is multiplied by $b-1$, then $1001_b$ is added, what is the result (written in base $b$)? The final Answer is 100100
 ### Proof
 We can write out what $11011_b$ means in terms of powers of $b$: $$11011_b = b^4+b^3+b+1.$$Multiplying this by $b-1$ gives \begin{align} 11011_b &= (b-1)b^4 + (b-1)b^3 + (b-1)b + (b-1) \\ &= b^5 - b^4 + b^4 - b^3 + b^2 - b + b - 1 \\

Instead of taking this algebraic approach, you can also think in terms of base-$b$ long arithmetic (note that each $(b-1)$ below represents a single digit): $$\begin{array}{r *5{c@{~}}c}
 && 1 & 1 & 0 & 1 & 1 \\ \times &&&&&& (b-1) \\ \hline && (b-1) & (b-1) & 0 & (b-1) & (b-1) \\ \\ \\ & \stackrel{1}{\phantom{(0)}} & \stackrel{1}{(b-1)} & (b-1) & \stackrel{1}{\phantom{(}0\phantom{)}} & \stackrel{1}{(b-1)} & (b-1) \\
 + &&& 1 & 0 & 0 & 1 \\ \hline & 1 & 0 & 0 & 1 & 0 & 0 \end{array}$$Note that no carries are needed in the multiplication step, since $b-1$ is a digit in base $b$. Carries are needed in the addition step, since $(b-1)+1=10_b$.
 *)

theorem
fixes b :: nat
assumes h0 : "b > 1"
shows  "(b^4 + b^3 + b + 1)*(b - 1) + b^3 + 1 = b^5 + b^2"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: Given a natural number $b$ greater than $1$, show that $(b^4 + b^3 + b + 1)(b - 1) + b^3 + 1 = b^5 + b^2$.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes b :: nat and f :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "f b = b * (b^4 + b^3 + b + 1) - 1"
and h1 : "f b + b^3 + 1 = b^5 + b^2"
shows  "f b = 100100"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 When the base-$b$ number $11011_b$ is multiplied by $b-1$, then $1001_b$ is added, what is the result (written in base $b$)? The final Answer is 100100
 ### Proof
 We can write out what $11011_b$ means in terms of powers of $b$: $$11011_b = b^4+b^3+b+1.$$Multiplying this by $b-1$ gives \begin{align} 11011_b &= (b-1)b^4 + (b-1)b^3 + (b-1)b + (b-1) \\ &= b^5 - b^4 + b^4 - b^3 + b^2 - b + b - 1 \\
 &= b^5 - b^3 + b^2 - 1. \end{align}Now $$1001_b = b^3 + 1,$$so when we add this to the result above, we get $b^5+b^2$, which is written in base $b$ as $\boxed{100100}$. Instead of taking this algebraic approach, you can also think in terms of base-$b$ long arithmetic (note that each $(b-1)$ below represents a single digit): $$\begin{array}{r *5{c@{~}}c}
 && 1 & 1 & 0 & 1 & 1 \\ \times &&&&&& (b-1) \\ \hline && (b-1) & (b-1) & 0 & (b-1) & (b-1) \\ \\ \\ & \stackrel{1}{\phantom{(0)}} & \stackrel{1}{(b-1)} & (b-1) & \stackrel{1}{\phantom{(}0\phantom{)}} & \stackrel{1}{(b-1)} & (b-1) \\
 + &&& 1 & 0 & 0 & 1 \\ \hline & 1 & 0 & 0 & 1 & 0 & 0 \end{array}$$Note that no carries are needed in the multiplication step, since $b-1$ is a digit in base $b$. Carries are needed in the addition step, since $(b-1)+1=10_b$.
 *)

theorem
fixes b :: nat and f :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "f b = b * (b^4 + b^3 + b + 1) - 1"
and h1 : "f b + b^3 + 1 = b^5 + b^2"
shows  "f b = 100100"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: Find a natural number $b$ such that $f(b) = b * (b^4 + b^3 + b + 1) - 1$ and $f(b) + b^3 + 1 = b^5 + b^2$. The final answer is $f(b) = 100100$.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes b :: real
assumes h0 : "b > 1"
and h1 : "11011 * (b - 1) + 1001 = 100100"
shows  "True"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 When the base-$b$ number $11011_b$ is multiplied by $b-1$, then $1001_b$ is added, what is the result (written in base $b$)? The final Answer is 100100
 ### Proof
 We can write out what $11011_b$ means in terms of powers of $b$: $$11011_b = b^4+b^3+b+1.$$Multiplying this by $b-1$ gives \begin{align} 11011_b &= (b-1)b^4 + (b-1)b^3 + (b-1)b + (b-1) \\ &= b^5 - b^4 + b^4 - b^3 + b^2 - b + b - 1 \\
 &= b^5 - b^3 + b^2 - 1. \end{align}Now $$1001_b = b^3 + 1,$$so when we add this to the result above, we get $b^5+b^2$, which is written in base $b$ as $\boxed{100100}$. Instead of taking this algebraic approach, you can also think in terms of base-$b$ long arithmetic (note that each $(b-1)$ below represents a single digit): $$\begin{array}{r *5{c@{~}}c}
 && 1 & 1 & 0 & 1 & 1 \\ \times &&&&&& (b-1) \\ \hline && (b-1) & (b-1) & 0 & (b-1) & (b-1) \\ \\ \\ & \stackrel{1}{\phantom{(0)}} & \stackrel{1}{(b-1)} & (b-1) & \stackrel{1}{\phantom{(}0\phantom{)}} & \stackrel{1}{(b-1)} & (b-1) \\
 + &&& 1 & 0 & 0 & 1 \\ \hline & 1 & 0 & 0 & 1 & 0 & 0 \end{array}$$Note that no carries are needed in the multiplication step, since $b-1$ is a digit in base $b$. Carries are needed in the addition step, since $(b-1)+1=10_b$.
 *)

theorem
fixes b :: real
assumes h0 : "b > 1"
and h1 : "11011 * (b - 1) + 1001 = 100100"
shows  "True"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: Find a real number $b$ greater than 1, that satisfies the equation $11011 \times (b - 1) + 1001 = 100100$.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes b :: real
assumes h0 : "b > 1"
and h1 : "b is integer"
shows  "b powr 4 + b powr 3 + b powr 1 + b powr 0 = (b - 1) * (b powr 4 + b powr 3 + b powr 1 + b powr 0) + (b powr 3 + b powr 0) = b powr 5 + b powr 4 + b powr 2"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 When the base-$b$ number $11011_b$ is multiplied by $b-1$, then $1001_b$ is added, what is the result (written in base $b$)? The final Answer is 100100
 ### Proof
 We can write out what $11011_b$ means in terms of powers of $b$: $$11011_b = b^4+b^3+b+1.$$Multiplying this by $b-1$ gives \begin{align} 11011_b &= (b-1)b^4 + (b-1)b^3 + (b-1)b + (b-1) \\ &= b^5 - b^4 + b^4 - b^3 + b^2 - b + b - 1 \\
 &= b^5 - b^3 + b^2 - 1. \end{align}Now $$1001_b = b^3 + 1,$$so when we add this to the result above, we get $b^5+b^2$, which is written in base $b$ as $\boxed{100100}$. Instead of taking this algebraic approach, you can also think in terms of base-$b$ long arithmetic (note that each $(b-1)$ below represents a single digit): $$\begin{array}{r *5{c@{~}}c}
 && 1 & 1 & 0 & 1 & 1 \\ \times &&&&&& (b-1) \\ \hline && (b-1) & (b-1) & 0 & (b-1) & (b-1) \\ \\ \\ & \stackrel{1}{\phantom{(0)}} & \stackrel{1}{(b-1)} & (b-1) & \stackrel{1}{\phantom{(}0\phantom{)}} & \stackrel{1}{(b-1)} & (b-1) \\
 + &&& 1 & 0 & 0 & 1 \\ \hline & 1 & 0 & 0 & 1 & 0 & 0 \end{array}$$Note that no carries are needed in the multiplication step, since $b-1$ is a digit in base $b$. Carries are needed in the addition step, since $(b-1)+1=10_b$.
 *)

theorem
fixes b :: real
assumes h0 : "b > 1"
and h1 : "b is integer"
shows  "b powr 4 + b powr 3 + b powr 1 + b powr 0 = (b - 1) * (b powr 4 + b powr 3 + b powr 1 + b powr 0) + (b powr 3 + b powr 0) = b powr 5 + b powr 4 + b powr 2"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: Given an integer $b$ greater than 1, show that $b^4 + b^3 + b + 1$ is equal to $(b - 1)(b^4 + b^3 + b + 1) + b^3 + 1$ which is also equal to $b^5 + b^4 + b^2$.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes b :: nat
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. b > 1 \<and> n \<ge> 0 \<longrightarrow> (n * (b-1) = n*(b-1))"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. b > 1 \<and> n \<ge> 0 \<longrightarrow> (n + 1001 = n + 1001)"
shows  "11011 * (b-1) + 1001 = 100100"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 When the base-$b$ number $11011_b$ is multiplied by $b-1$, then $1001_b$ is added, what is the result (written in base $b$)? The final Answer is 100100
 ### Proof
 We can write out what $11011_b$ means in terms of powers of $b$: $$11011_b = b^4+b^3+b+1.$$Multiplying this by $b-1$ gives \begin{align} 11011_b &= (b-1)b^4 + (b-1)b^3 + (b-1)b + (b-1) \\ &= b^5 - b^4 + b^4 - b^3 + b^2 - b + b - 1 \\
 &= b^5 - b^3 + b^2 - 1. \end{align}Now $$1001_b = b^3 + 1,$$so when we add this to the result above, we get $b^5+b^2$, which is written in base $b$ as $\boxed{100100}$. Instead of taking this algebraic approach, you can also think in terms of base-$b$ long arithmetic (note that each $(b-1)$ below represents a single digit): $$\begin{array}{r *5{c@{~}}c}
 && 1 & 1 & 0 & 1 & 1 \\ \times &&&&&& (b-1) \\ \hline && (b-1) & (b-1) & 0 & (b-1) & (b-1) \\ \\ \\ & \stackrel{1}{\phantom{(0)}} & \stackrel{1}{(b-1)} & (b-1) & \stackrel{1}{\phantom{(}0\phantom{)}} & \stackrel{1}{(b-1)} & (b-1) \\
 + &&& 1 & 0 & 0 & 1 \\ \hline & 1 & 0 & 0 & 1 & 0 & 0 \end{array}$$Note that no carries are needed in the multiplication step, since $b-1$ is a digit in base $b$. Carries are needed in the addition step, since $(b-1)+1=10_b$.
 *)

theorem
fixes b :: nat
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. b > 1 \<and> n \<ge> 0 \<longrightarrow> (n * (b-1) = n*(b-1))"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. b > 1 \<and> n \<ge> 0 \<longrightarrow> (n + 1001 = n + 1001)"
shows  "11011 * (b-1) + 1001 = 100100"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem:
Assume that for all nonnegative numbers $n$, the following two conditions hold: 
1) If $b$ is greater than 1, then $n*(b-1)$ equals $n*(b-1)$,
2) If $b$ is greater than 1, then $n+1001$ equals $n+1001$.
Given these assumptions, prove that $11011*(b-1) + 1001 = 100100$.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes b :: nat and n m :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> i. n i = 1 * b powr (4-i) + 1 * b powr (3-i) + 0 * b powr (2-i) + 1 * b powr (1-i) + 1 * b powr (0-i)"
and h1 : "\<forall> i. m i = 1 * b powr (3-i) + 0 * b powr (2-i) + 0 * b powr (1-i) + 1 * b powr (0-i)"
and h2 : "\<forall> i. n i * (b - 1) + m i = 1 * b powr (5-i) + 0 * b powr (4-i) + 0 * b powr (3-i) + 1 * b powr (2-i) + 0 * b powr (1-i) + 0 * b powr (0-i)"
shows  "\<forall> i. n i * (b - 1) + m i = 1 * b powr (5-i) + 0 * b powr (4-i) + 0 * b powr (3-i) + 1 * b powr (2-i) + 0 * b powr (1-i) + 0 * b powr (0-i)"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 When the base-$b$ number $11011_b$ is multiplied by $b-1$, then $1001_b$ is added, what is the result (written in base $b$)? The final Answer is 100100
 ### Proof
 We can write out what $11011_b$ means in terms of powers of $b$: $$11011_b = b^4+b^3+b+1.$$Multiplying this by $b-1$ gives \begin{align} 11011_b &= (b-1)b^4 + (b-1)b^3 + (b-1)b + (b-1) \\ &= b^5 - b^4 + b^4 - b^3 + b^2 - b + b - 1 \\
 &= b^5 - b^3 + b^2 - 1. \end{align}Now $$1001_b = b^3 + 1,$$so when we add this to the result above, we get $b^5+b^2$, which is written in base $b$ as $\boxed{100100}$. Instead of taking this algebraic approach, you can also think in terms of base-$b$ long arithmetic (note that each $(b-1)$ below represents a single digit): $$\begin{array}{r *5{c@{~}}c}
 && 1 & 1 & 0 & 1 & 1 \\ \times &&&&&& (b-1) \\ \hline && (b-1) & (b-1) & 0 & (b-1) & (b-1) \\ \\ \\ & \stackrel{1}{\phantom{(0)}} & \stackrel{1}{(b-1)} & (b-1) & \stackrel{1}{\phantom{(}0\phantom{)}} & \stackrel{1}{(b-1)} & (b-1) \\
 + &&& 1 & 0 & 0 & 1 \\ \hline & 1 & 0 & 0 & 1 & 0 & 0 \end{array}$$Note that no carries are needed in the multiplication step, since $b-1$ is a digit in base $b$. Carries are needed in the addition step, since $(b-1)+1=10_b$.
 *)

theorem
fixes b :: nat and n m :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> i. n i = 1 * b powr (4-i) + 1 * b powr (3-i) + 0 * b powr (2-i) + 1 * b powr (1-i) + 1 * b powr (0-i)"
and h1 : "\<forall> i. m i = 1 * b powr (3-i) + 0 * b powr (2-i) + 0 * b powr (1-i) + 1 * b powr (0-i)"
and h2 : "\<forall> i. n i * (b - 1) + m i = 1 * b powr (5-i) + 0 * b powr (4-i) + 0 * b powr (3-i) + 1 * b powr (2-i) + 0 * b powr (1-i) + 0 * b powr (0-i)"
shows  "\<forall> i. n i * (b - 1) + m i = 1 * b powr (5-i) + 0 * b powr (4-i) + 0 * b powr (3-i) + 1 * b powr (2-i) + 0 * b powr (1-i) + 0 * b powr (0-i)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem:
Given a base $b$ and two sequences of natural numbers $n$ and $m$ such that:

- $n_i = b^{4-i} + b^{3-i} + b^{1-i} + b^{0-i}$ for all $i$.
- $m_i = b^{3-i} + b^{0-i}$ for all $i$.

Prove that for all $i$, $n_i \cdot (b - 1) + m_i = b^{5-i} + b^{2-i}$.
